definition: Easily seen or noticed; attracting attention.
examples: Her bright coat made her conspicuous in the crowd.
The error was conspicuous on the first page.

definition: To separate people or things from a larger group, often unfairly.
examples: It is wrong to segregate pupils by background.
Recycling plants segregate plastics by type.

definition: A very dirty and unpleasant condition, often due to poverty or neglect.
examples: The abandoned building had fallen into squalor.
They worked to lift families out of squalor.

definition: To fall very quickly and suddenly; a weight used to find a vertical line (noun).
examples: Temperatures plummeted overnight. (verb)
Builders used a plummet to check the wall. (noun)

definition: Able to do many different things well; having many uses.
examples: A versatile tool can tighten or cut.
She’s a versatile performer—she sings and dances.

definition: To tame an animal or adapt a plant for human use; to make something more home-like.
examples: Early farmers domesticated wild wheat.
Cats were domesticated thousands of years ago.

extra.memory_tip: Domesticate = make fit for the home (domus).

definition: Dull and repetitive; lacking variety in sound or activity.
examples: The monotonous beeping kept us awake.
Copying notes became monotonous.

definition: A journey with a specific purpose, especially exploration or research.
examples: They joined an expedition to the reef.
The expedition gathered valuable samples.

definition: Continuing forever or for a very long time without stopping.
examples: They lived in perpetual daylight in midsummer.
His perpetual optimism lifted the team.

definition: Fully in agreement; with everyone of the same opinion.
examples: The decision was unanimous.
The judges were unanimous in their praise.

definition: A guard or lookout who watches for danger.
examples: A lone sentinel stood at the gate.
Tall pines acted as sentinels along the ridge.

definition: Not aware of or not concerned about what is happening around you.
examples: He walked on, oblivious to the rain.
She was oblivious to the whispers.

extra.memory_tip: Oblivious = obvious things can be invisible to you.

definition: To give up or let go of something, often unwillingly.
examples: She relinquished control of the project.
They reluctantly relinquished their claim.

extra.memory_tip: Relinquish = release your link to it.

definition: Worried or fearful that something bad might happen.
examples: She felt apprehensive before the exam.
He was apprehensive about the storm.

definition: Dangerous because of hidden or unpredictable hazards; not trustworthy.
examples: The icy road was treacherous.
They avoided the treacherous guide.
